We had already had 8 nights in Shibuya at the Tobu, but had one last night in Tokyo and decided to splurge so went for the Excel.This hotel is beautiful and fantastically located so we could walk straight off the JR Yamanote line and into the hotel with our luggage. We were a little early (12:30) so the hotel kindly offered to mind our bags.At 2pm our room was ready and we were on the 15th floor - we caught the outdoor/clear lift which I was a little excited about because of the amazing view it afforded us of Shibuya.The room was relatively spacious but the bed was smaller than I expected - that said it was a semi-double so I shouldn't have been surprised. The view from our window was great especially at night and the view from the elevator area on each floor is spectacular - the ultimate view of the Shibuya crossing.I couldn't for the life of me work out the internet - had easy plug in ethernet at every other hotel that worked straight away but this I couldn't figure out. We were only staying one night so I didn't bother to ask staff for help. I did ask staff at reception for help to get to Haneda considering I didn't have the internet and they were incredibly helpful.This hotel is gorgeous and I was happy enough with it - the room was much bigger and nicer than we had experienced at other places. That said, I think I'd rather keep my money for the shops and stay somewhere smaller/simpler... this was a bit of a splurge. If money is no object, go for it!

this hotel was awesome- when we got off the train to look for our hotel, it was so nice to see a sign at the shibuya train station directing us to our hotel because its connected to the station! rooms were a good size and bed was comfy. the elevators are cool too because they look down on the shibuya crossing. my two complaints were that they didn't include a breakfast, but that was actually ok because they are connected to the Mark West mall, where they have PLENTY of food options- and they have a plastic bathroom- ugh! go check out the restaurant on the 25th floor though- they have some great views up there!

This hotel is located at Shibuya Mark City which is below the train station and Ginza subway line. There's nothing to dislike about this hotel. Rooms were spacious, and clean. Housekeeping is excellent, and very meticulous (just like the Japanese people).You get dropped off at the doorstep (literally a few steps away from the front door) with the airport limo bus that services both airports (Narita and Haneda).Secondly, there are restaurants, cafes, convenience store and shops just below the hotel.And lastly, everything else is just a walk away - from restaurants, fast food chains, cafes, local shops, departmental stores, and flagship stores (H&M, Loft, Forever 21, Tokyu Hands).You must eat at the hotel's restaurant on the 25th floor. It offers fantastic view of the city and beyond. On a clear day, you can even see Mount Fuji.Shibuya is also connected to many popular places with the Yamanote Line - Shinjuku, Harujuku, Yoyogi are just minutes away.

Location was great. Right on top of access to public transport. Main entrance spills out into mid Shibuya so great shopping and unbelievable food right around the corner.Rooms were good. Missing some of the standard amenities like iron, ironing board, etc but still nice. Slight communication issues attempting to get said items but turned out ok. Rooms were very clean, bathroom was good size, updated, water pressure was good. My room had a wonderful view of the Shibuya area and beyond, including the mountain range in the background.Did not dine in the hotel because great food was right around the corner. Leave the hotel, hand a left and get lost in the side streets of Shibuya, you are guaranteed to find good food in small hole in the walls - be adventurous. Staff was very helpful. Had some complicated requests due to paying for all of my business colleagues that arrived and left on different days - hotel staff handled it in stride and nothing was mishandled.

An amazing hotel right in the heart of Shibuya with awesome views. Even better if you can get a deal..I paid £100GBP a night..think that was half price. When I come through this way again it will be the place to stay..decent sized room for Tokyo..easy street access and a great view for breakfast..recommended.

This hotel is in the best possible location in Shibuya - litterally right on top of the mass transit, steps away from EVERYTHING!!We paid about 230$ per night. Our room was big, modern, super comfortable and the view was incredible. I would definitely stay there again.

Stayed 5 nights at the Shibuya Excel Hotel in Tokyo this Fall 2011. It is steps from the train station, which makes it a breeze to get to from the airport, to access the subway, etc. The hotel is very nice, the rooms are not as small as in other places in Tokyo (I had a double bed, a desk, a vanity counter...) and the service was great - the concierge really helped me with lots of questions, from restaurants to transportation, and had an umbrella handy for me on a rainny day. The two restaurants cater to both Asia and Western tastes, so all is covered.
I found this hotel so well placed.Connected to the metro station,it really made my trip much easier. I am very glad to choose it and I will do it again on my next trip to Japon

The hotel is in a great area , close to shopping and all the areas you want to be in this area. The hotel was clean and well kept, the staff was helpful and polite.. There is no mini bar just an empty fridge. My only big issue is the bed. I have never in my life had a more horrible night sleep on a mattress. There are two mattress in the room on is like hard straw and the other is springs covered in cloth. It's beyond horrible. I even tried stacking them on top of each other but still the worst. If you are used to a good mattress at a nicer hotel don't come here. This hotel is in need of more modern beds and that's about the only thing that really stuck with me.

We all know Tokyo hotel rooms are small; even so, this was something! But the location is unbeatable, with vertiginous views down on scurrying salarymen and glaring neon. You are absurdly spoilt for choice with all the local eateries, and the metro is very convenient. The hotel has an excellent Japanese breakfast too, eaten on the top floor while watching teh Tokyo skyline. Very good.

Rooms are small (but then hey, this is downtown Tokyo),but very clean and functional. Bed is very comfortable. Highspeed internet is free - and fast. Breakfast is not included (approx. USD 30 in top storey level restaurant which offers sunning vistas of Tokyo.) Nearby Shibuya is bussling with hundreds of small restaurants and bars. Hotel reception is at the fifth floor, and for those not familiar with Japanese downtown hotels not easy to find - need to go through a labyrinth of stores and train / subway stations. Rail and bus link to Narita airport easy.

My family of 4 stayed 5 nights at the Shibuya Excel Tokyu Hotel (July 1-6 2011) in a quad room with 4 beds. It was great.Likes :)- great to have a room with 4 beds (no one had to share)...quad rooms are hard to find in Tokyo- modern, clean and good size room (easily fit our 3-4 suitcases)- toilet is separate from bath/shower- comfortable beds- great location...steps away from subway and JR station- great shopping location...steps away from department stores and restaurants- very polite and helpful front desk and housekeeping staff- free WiFi internet included in room price- good price found on ExpediaDislikes :(- only weird thing is that the hotel doesn't have a traditional front entrance...but this is not a big issue for us. The airport limo dropped us off right at the back dropoff entrance

We stayed here in July 2010 and found it to be an excellent hotel. In fact it was the nicest hotel we stayed in while spending three weeks in Japan. I loved the staff and the location. It is right on the famous Shibuya intersection. We were in the 25th floor in a triple room and had an excellent view of everything. It is conveniently located steps from the Shibuya JR station and under the station is the Tokyo Food Show which house a grocery store and many individual food stalls. Yum!

Outstanding location, great views - right in the heart of Shibuya. Rooms a bit lackluster, but price is good and everything worked and was reliable. Only noteworthy drawback is that it was - somehow, despite my high floor - still extremely loud in the room with ambient street noise / music. I typically have an extremely high tolerance for this after living in the middle of a city - I think it was some kind of loudspeaker / music event that was happening that was the problem. Would check other reviews - perhaps my experience was just because of some event that day. Would recommend, but for a bit more, I preferred the Cerulean just around the corner (although Excel was definitely less expensive when I went).

It was a 12 day trip and in the usual Japanese way, the rooms are very small (declared for 1 pax) compared to other countries that I have been to.Reception spoke excellent English so getting information was never an issue. I have totally no complaints about the hotel, as my room on the 23rd security floor had a great view. Internet speed was excellent and the room was comfortable enough for me.Breakfast was acceptable with a Western and Japanese mix. Problem is that on some busy days, you probably have to sit out and wait for a table as one of the restaurants on the 25th floor is being renovated during the time of my visit. Restaurant location on the 25th floor was a plus as you'd be having food overlooking the city.The room has everything you need for a pleasure or business traveller. What I like was not the small puny shampoo, conditioner bottles but full size ones. They give you a hairbrushes, hair dryer, and an empty fridge so stock up yourself. 7-11 or 24 hour Family marts are 100 steps away only. The hotel sits right on top of Shibuya Mark City, and all around within a 20 min radius is shopping heaven ... if you are a teenager.Also the fact that Shibuya station has the Narita Express which runs straight to the station from the airport (1 hr 20 min journey at 3100 yen), walk out and you are looking at the hotel. And because Shibuya seems to be an intersection line, you could hitch a train ride from this station to almost anywhere in Tokyo.The area is vibrant and restaurants abound and aplenty, though you would have greater choices if you speak Japanese. However, you have your usual Macdonalds and Burger King, and Outback Steakhouse and Dubliners which could get you eating well, if you miss your Western type steak or burgers. Its a nice variation with Kebab and Indian food also to be found. If you are an avid shopper, then this is the place to go.Shibuya boast a younger crowd mix, and if you dont like crowds, you have to live with it. But it is a great location to find strange looking fashion like purple bleach hair, or even manga style fashionistas walking around.If you would like a more mature type of group, Roppongi or Shinjiku is just a few stations away where the more foreigner friendly crowd are. Nothing dangerous here except for the occasional drunk teenagers around 2 am onwards puking their guts out.On an overall, no complaints except at S$300 per night, it is on the high side ... but then again, with location comes price.
Very nice.Convenient location, nice room. Nothing spectacular, but still very nice.

This was our 6th hotel on our 8 city visit to Asia, but our first hotel in Japan. The amenity focus is different in Japan than other countries, not better or worse, just a different focus. The area looked great, I was wishing I arrived before 11:30pm (or that I didn't have to get up at 7am). The room was smaller than the previous 5 on this visit, but functional. All in all, a good Japan hotel.

Location is great and so many options for eating and shopping around the area. Rooms were of good size yet for the standard of this hotel I would have expected more.If you want a peaceful sleep you wont want to stay at this hotel as being right on top of the station you get trains going past every 2 mins from about 6 am - midnight!
Being literally on top of the Shibuya Station, you can easily get here from the airport, and all around Tokyo. It's a great part of Shibuya, and a very convenient place to host first time visitors.

The location is AMAZING about his hotel. It is in the middle of everything, center of everything, and I can't ask for a better location than this hotel. The rooms are not so great because it is very smoky and you are allowed to smoke in the rooms, so it smells like cigarettes. The bathroom is clean, small, the room, even though it is smoky, was pretty clean.I think it's a good deal for the price I paid considering the location. It really is in the heart of shibuya and on top of the station. The reception desk was pretty friendly and the stay was decent. You have a great view of the city from the hotel. You can take a shuttle bus that takes you to diff hotels from the airport, and I think it was about an hour ride or less, I don't recall exactly. I would stay here again because it is really decently priced for the location and if you are a smoker, I think you are going to be ok here. Overall, I think this isn't a fancy hotel, but a pretty good priced hotel for what you pay with excellent location.

Great hotel in the center of Shibuya. Everything is a footstep away: Metro lines, airport shuttle, famous departments stores and night life.The hotel is clean, great stuff that react fast, great view over the city. Secured elevators (2 are facing outward - a must view).Semi-double rooms may be small from some, but are great for couples. There is a "Foodshow" market and food floor under the hotel, worth visiting there and taking some great food to your room - don't miss it!Highly recommended hotel in Tokyo

If you think Shibuya is an ideal location and you want to choose this hotel because of this, you would make the wrong decision like I did. The hotel is not exactly connected to Shibuya station, it's about 10 minutes walk from Yamanote line, Hachiko exit. Believe me it's not easy when you have to walk through busy Shibuya with luggages.The reception staff is rude. Make sure when you book the room (especially through Japanican) that you get non-smoking room. It the room type does not indicate explicitly as non-smoking, you will end up getting smoking room/ floor.
reception team is bad; rude and unhelpful. we booked non-smoking room. they end up putting us in smoking room and smoking floor. terrible experience!!!

Asalamu alakumok so lets get this show cracking. First things first, this hotel is a great hotel in the perfect location. I said perfect location! You just cant beat it, if its your first visit to tokyo and you want to be within walking distance to shops, halal food, amenities, rail station and the madness of japanese fashion. Its the equivalent to staying in oxford street with, regents park and Piccadilly down the road so expect the same type of atmosphere.And just for the record, most people speak english or will make an effort to speak english. Which is more than i can say for english speakers, because im sure you wouldn't try and speak japanese if you were approached in your own country by a japanese tourist.Ok so let me break things down for you for those people who want a step by step guide.-Airport to hotel.Get the airport limo (which is a coach) to the hotel, when you come of arrivals after collecting your luggage, the desks are right in front of you, just go up and tell them shibuya excel hotel and they will sell you a ticket for 3000 Yen and direct you to the bus stop which is just outside the entrance doors. Your ticket will have a time on it, they run around every 15 mins, and are ON TIME!.  Its gonna take you around 1 hr 30 -2 hours to get to the hotel, the time varies on rush hour traffic, but hey its a free sightseeing tour of the city. You can put as much luggage as you want and youll be given a ticket for each piece of luggage. When you get off the coach allow the driver to empty out all the luggage first then he will ask for your ticket. Be patient they are very quick. Shibuya excel is the last stop so you wont get lost, as the coach announcement speaks in english. There are about 3 stops all in all, and theres a toilet on the coach.When you get off the limo, the entrance is directly in front of you around 100 metres, walk through the doors pass the toilets on the left and turn right after the vending machines and your in the main lobby and the reception desk can be seen. This is actually the 5 floor of the building and if you want to go to street level you'll just get the elevator down. -Checking injust give them your passport and let them do the rest. We arrived at 12:00 and were allowed to check in early by a very nice staff member. -staffAs i said earlier they all speak english and are very helpful. -RoomRoom has a flat screen tv, table and chairs, bedside remote control for lights and aircon.Daily supply of razors, earbuds, shower caps, toothbrushes and toothpaste, face flannel.House keeping stops at 3pm and you have to ring them after 11 to have your room cleaned before 3pm. Normally they phone your room if you have the don't disturb sign up, to confirm if your want your room cleaned or not.-Family friendlyOf course, japanese people do have children too,lol So yes you do see parents with buggies and baby slings in and around the hotel. Even the department stores have their own children buggies that you can use.-LocationYou are so central its unbelievable, The train station is beneath your feet and mark city department store are all attached to the same building. Shibuya hotel occupies 5th floor upwards. -Food there is a vending machine and ice machine on each floor. Dont be silly enough to just room service at those prices, when you've got so many cheaper options on your doorstep.Being muslim in a non muslim country you may think that halal food is hard to find, but think again. *Halal meat is the meat of an animal over which the verbal sentence "In the name of God" was said before the animal was killed for the intention of eating. Muslims seeking halal meat just go look out for any kebab shop, the are owned by muslim turkish people and the chicken in halal. Also there is are a couple of indian restaurants (eat as much as you can rice and nan!) called Samarat, they are within 5 mins walk from opposite the hotel, near centre gai. Walk down the street of the big Adidas shop its at the street of the side entrance of tokyo hands just for this address if you cant find it. The address is: KIRAKU Bldg.,B1.,29-2, UDAGAWA-CHO, SHIBUYA-KU, TOKYO. Phone: 03-3770-7286 -OPEN EVERY DAY-FROM : 11:00A.M.～11:00P.M.But i didn't come to japan for dirty kebabs and curry, although i did indulge a couple of times. I came for the sushi and noodles, yeahhh bruv! If you think youve been eating sushi in the UK, then think again, because japan sushi is on a different level. The freshness of the fish is the first sensation that enters the mouth. If you aint had sushi in japan then you aint had sushi, game time my friend! Noodle bars every where, dont be scared of the locals, just man up and go in sit down and order. Or just point to some thing that makes your mouth water, they have these plastic models of the food on offer. And the food actual comes out looking like it. Learn some basic japanese words, like fish, no pork, vegetarian it will prove to be most helpful for you.also Mark city the building of your hotel has an amazing food court in the basement B1, just go to the street floor level and get the escalators down to the b1 floor. And note that after 8:00pm most foods are reduced!!! sushi every ting. Look to spend roughly from £3 -£ infinity, it just depends on your budget. A bottle of coke is around £1.30p and a bar of chocolate is about £1 in 7/11's and family mart (the japanese 7/11. From whale meat to octopus balls its here in shibuya. -NappiesYou can find nappies just ask for diapers in the toddler section of the Toyku department store.-money exchangethere is a bank downstairs on your left just before the shibuya crossing, go in and get the lift to the second floor which is the money exchange floor to change your money to Yen. Also you can exchange in the airport, youll have to fill in a piece of paper wih the amount yo want to change then had it to the cashier.Thats it im done, too much just get yourself to JP, shibuya excel hotel. Good service, friendly staff best location.peace

Granted, the location of this hotel is second to none, the view from our room was out of this world, but that is all I have good to say about this hotel. The reception staff were extremely rude and unhelpful. I booked a semi-double, led to believe this was two double beds. Travelling with a friend, I did not expect us to be sharing a small double together for the night. I informed reception of the mix up, to which I got a response 'a lot of people think its two doubles, but it is in fact a smaller than average single double'. They were not prepared to rectify this without charging a considerable amount more to upgrade. The room was small and old fashioned. None of the nice extras you would expect when paying this much for a hotel. There is free wi-fi available but no computer, so for those travelling without a laptop have to pay 100Yen per 10 minutes on a computer tucked away in a claustrophobic and cramped room.After 2 weeks travelling, I thought this would be a night of relexation and luxury, sadly it was far from that!

My husband and I were travelling with another couple and I booked 2 rooms at this hotel based on its location and a good rate that I found on hotels.com. It's is located literally right at the famed Shibuya crossing, with heaps of great shopping, restaurants/food stalls, bars, clubs, convenience stores and the train station just below. Another nearby attraction is the statue of the Hachiko (the loyal dog), which is just opposite the hotel. I found the hotel to be very conveniently located for what we wanted to do (shopping and eating!). On one of the days we were there, we even walked all the way back to the hotel from Harajuku because there were so many things to see along the way!Rooms - a very comfortable size, considering what I had been told about Tokyo hotels. Bathroom was also a decent size, clean,with good water pressure and nice Pola (a Japanese beauty brand) toiletries. Free internet was great. We initially had some trouble connecting to the internet with our laptop, but this was quickly and professionally rectified by one of the hotel's staff, despite the fact that I had rung for help quite late in the night.Very happy with our stay there, would definitely go back.

On our recent visit to Tokyo we spent 2 nights in Shinjuku & decided to spend the last 3 nights in Shibuya at this Hotel. The main reason for paying what was essentially double the cost of the Shinjuku accomodation, was the fabulous position [& view] over this famous crossing. We booked a standard queen room, but upon checking in found that the view was obstructed by buildings - we were not directly looking down on the crossing as I expected we would be. Upon checking with Hotel Staff, I was told only the Twin rooms look directly down at the crossing. They were not particularly interested in helping me out by moving us. All in all the room was fine, but I was disappointed in view :(

This hotel met our needs well. For location it couldn't have been better, overlooking the shibuya crossing from the lift, our room, the restaurant. Shibuya is an amazing area and seems never to sleep, even looking out my window at 4am, 6am, still lots of people on the streets. Plenty of places to eat, drink and shop.The rooms are small, but this is Tokyo. The price was outrageous, but this is tokyo. Otherwise, it was clean, comfy beds, lots of accessories provided such as earbuds, hairbrush, toothbrush etc. We struggled to persuade the hotel to lend us champagne glasses and they insisted they did not have any. Eventually they sent us the champagne glasses to our room.

We've just arrived from a two weeks trip in Japan, out of which one week in Tokyo, in Shibuya Exel Hotel.We traveled with kids (3 and 6), so we looked for a convenient location from the transportation point of view. I'll make a short review of what in our opinions are the strong and the weak points of this hotel:Pluses:1. Perfectly connected with the airport - limousine bus (www.limousinebus.co.jp/en/) stops right at the hotel - no reservations are made for the arrival - we purchased the tickets directly from the airport but for the return the reservation is mandatory - we just asked the lady at the hotel's reception one day in advance to help us and she called the company. Also very convenient that all luggage is managed by the hotel from the hotel to bus and we didn't have to look after the kids and trail the suitcases as well2. Perfectly connected with subway and JR lines as the hotel itself occupies floors 5-25 from the building and the Shibuya station is on the 3rd floor. Commutation to all the places we visited was as easy at it can be in a city of Tokyo's size.3. very vivid location as Shibuya is busy all the time, whole streets of restaurants opened late in the evening, shops and crowds of young people, some of them dressed in the Harajuku-style, so quite spectacular4. Pleasant and helpful staff5. Spectacular views over Tokyo from the A Bientot restaurant on the 25th floor, where the western style breakfast buffet is servedMinuses:1. Furniture and bath a bit dated2. Small rooms and no baby cot available for our 3 year old - we have ask for one upon making the reservation, but the hotel had only baby cots for up to 2 year olds - apparently would not hold an older baby. In the Kyoto hotel we stayed for the next week it was not a problem to arrange for the baby cot.3. No free wi-fi - actually this is valid for all places we traveled in Tokyo and Kansai - quite a significant nuisance4. Breakfast was served in two alternatives, in two different restaurants- Japanese - with a set menu and Western - buffet. Since our kids would not really manage with the Japanese option, we went for the Western alternative which was mostly Western indeed, with no fusion dishes as we would have hoped while being in Japan. Also a drawback was an almost daily waiting queue to get to the breakfast table. The waiting was nicely managed though, with a long chain of chairs all facing the glass walls and the beautiful scenery over Tokyo and in the end was not really uncomfortable. A bit annoying was the lack of variation in the menu - every day mostly the same for the whole week.So all in all, we thought it was a perfect location, a nice hotel with kind and helpful staff.As of the program while traveling with kids, we tried to make half of the objectives for them and half for us and it worked well as long as we grouped things in the same area. For the kids we went in Odaiba to the Emerging Science and Innovation Museum (www.miraikan.jst.go.jp/en/) than we took the river trip on the Sumida river till Asakusa and Senso Ji Temple. From the museum there is a free bus that goes around Odaiba and stops to major attractions. So we took the bus till Seaside Park. We were lucky to catch the last boat (water bus) at 6.30 (we understood that in non-holiday season the last boat is around 5.15pm). The water bus schedule is onhttp://www.suijobus.co.jp/ We also went to the Roppongi Mori Art Museum which w found small but with exhibits of exquisite quality, to The Tokyo Museum of Modern Art - small and an unfortunate choice for us - far and mostly with common pieces of art (we understood the the collection is vast but only several pieces are on display at a time and we were not lucky in our opinion at least).Also for the kids we went to the Ueno zoo - pretty instructive since they were running an exhibition on the evolution of legs from fish to mammals. We found Shinjuku and Harajuku aquite outstanding from the architecture and people point of view.

Location is flawless, just besides JR and a couple of train/ subway positions and it is besides numerous coach positions too. Department shops and stores are just below and nearby. Staff are very amicable and cooperative even a couple of of them don't talk much English. This is the third time I resided there. The beds and the slips are habitually clean and quiet place but the central may need some updating.

Was lucky to get an upgrade and stayed on the 24th floor from which we enjoyed a stunning view over Shibuya and towards the centre of Tokyo. The elevator also had a fantastic view of the Shibuya crossing. The room was very comfortable and spacious and dominated by a large window. The bathroom was also very large with room for a full sized bath. Location-wise the hotel was excellent above a shopping centre which is built into the Shibuya station, I would thoroughly recommend the hotel to anyone who wants to splurge during their stay.

The Shibuya Excel is perfectly located in the heart of Shibuya. The staff are great, the room we had was so quiet and yet directly out the front door we could step into the busiest part of Tokyo. MUST SEE - we stumbled upon the most amazing food hall you can imagine directly underneath the hotel - 'Food Show' is two levels of gorgeous food at reasonable prices.

A buddy and I were on an Asia tour to celebrate getting into law school. We stayed at 9 hotels over a three and half week trip to Japan, Thailand and Cambodia. I personally have been to Tokyo three times before and stayed at 4 hotels at varies areas of Tokyo. This was the most expensive hotel that we stayed in ($350+ a night) and by far the worst. The service was horrible. No one welcomed us when we arrived. No one offered to take our bags when arrived or when we were leaving to catch our taxi to Narita. When we asked them to help us arrange transportation to Narita, they were less then helpful and very rude. They did not show us to our room. When we explained why we were disappointed with the service to the receptionist, she did little more than say that she was sorry in perhaps in a incredibly disingenuous manner.The room was tiny, which is not the surprising for Tokyo, but was ridiculous for the price. It was also filthy. We found hair in the sink and in the bathtub. Also, the furniture and appliances in the room reminded me of a Super 8 or a Best Western here in the States. I am not sure if the air conditioning was broken, but it was about 85 degrees in the lobby and probably about 90 in our room.The only real benefits of this hotel is that it has a view of Shibuya and it is right next to Shibuya station. However, there are plenty of hotels next to metro stations and depending on what you intend to see in Tokyo, there are a lot of hotels next to more convenient metro stations. Additionally, the view we had from a our room was ok at best. Shibuya is kind of like Times Square except less touristy and trashy, so if that is what you want to see then maybe this hotel is for you. But, you can have better views of Tokyo in nicer more convenient areas, with cleaner rooms, much better service and at half the price.I will be returning to Tokyo, but I will certainly not be returning to this hotel.

We booked this hotel solely on location and relative price - and were not at all disappointed. We normally avoid large hotels, but on this occasion we weren't disappointed. You can literally walk directly from Shibuya station across the overpass to one of the many entrances to the hotel (Tip: look out for the small signs and markings on the floor near elevator entrances, some of which we overlooked initially). Note that the lobby is on the 5th floor. On arrival we were offered a room upgrade for a small sum - which we were happy we agreed to - the room was 6 metres larger, huge by Japanese standards and had a king size bed which was pure luxury after sleeping on a futon for a few days! The room was clean and comfortable - and had an excellent view - but really, in this case, it's all about convenience and location. Walk straight outside into the midst of everything. And the airport limousine arrives and departs directly from this hotel every day, which is an added bonus. For the price, it can't be beat! We will stay there again for certain.

Narita Express brought me to Sibuya station and this hotel was just above the station. I took METRO( Ginza Subway line) every day and the subway entrance was really close to he hotel, so it was really convenient ( You can take JR loop line (Yamanote line ) too)I stayed at 14th floor and had a nice view from there. There were western and Japanese restaurant at 25th floor. I had a breakfast there and It was awesome. Nice view and nice food.There were bunch of eating and shopping place in Sibuya just outside of the hotel. I went to UNIQLO and Tokyu Hands, Seibu Department strore. My room was upgraded to the Double bed room( which is slightly smaller than the king size bed of US) and spacious enough as a Japanese hotel. The usage of the internet was free.You can not go directly to the guest room. You ve got to change elevators at front lobby floor. It was sometimes troublesome for me but good security for everyone.The shuttle bus to the Haneda and Narita airport also stop this hotel. I took one to the Haneda airport.

My partner and I recently spend a week and a half at the Shibuya Excel as part of our honeymoon.We chose this hotel after reading some favourable reviews in tripadvisor. We caught the Limousine Bus from Narita (a very simple and easy way to get to Tokyo) which dropped us off right at the hotels door. The check-in process was quick and easy, with the staff being polite, friendly and also a good command of english. Our room was upgraded from a semi-double room to a premiere (or excel premiere) double to our surprise our room was quite small (but large for Tokyo standards from what we were told) but nicely furnished. The room included a flat screen tv, desk/dresser (which are not included in some Tokyo hotel rooms) and a couple of chairs and a table next to the window from where we were able to look over the famous Shibuya crossing from the 22nd floor with views of the park where Meiji-Jingu shrine is located and the Shinjuku buildings in the distance (quite a sight at night time).The location of the hotel isn't very central as it is quite far from some neighbourhoods: Ginza and Akihabara for example (is there a central location in Tokyo?) however the close proximity to the JR Yamanote line and the Tokyo Metro station and also the simplicity of using the trains make up for this. Also the hotel is located just above a shopping complex - Mark City and also not far from a great food hall in the basement of Tokyu department store which adjoins Shibuya metro station. The surrounding area stays up late and there are large number of eateries, coffee shops and well known stores ie Uni Qlo, Don Quixote, Tokyu Hands some open till very late (some 24 hours) which was very convenient.The cleanliness of our room could not be faulted and was serviced everyday to a high standard. There was also a vending machine on our floor selling bottled water, beers and soft drinks which came in very handy. The hotel concierge was very helpful and was always able to help with our queries, all the staff that we dealt with were able to speak english (at various levels) but there no communication problems.All in all a good experience, nothing too fancy but modern, neat and tidy - great if you are sight seeing. Recommended, we would definitely consider staying here again.

You just can't find a better place to stay in Tokyo. Hotel is right above Shibuya station. I stayed there 3 nights and requested a crossing street view. Though the room is relatively small, everything else is fabulous. Bathroom is sort of disappointed. They could have done better cleaning. Highly recommend for those who are looking for places to stay in Tokyo.

Clean Modern Hotel in the heart of Tokyo.The Excel hotel is above the Mark City shopping complex overlooking the famous pedestrian crossing in Shibuya. The area is similar to Time Square or Piccadilly Circus.Our semi double room was a good size, but the bed was small for 2 people, and I would recommend upgrading to a double room if you aren't super skinny or are going to be there for any period of time. We upgraded and the double room we were given was fine. It was on the 14th floor with a great view of the crossing and hustle and bustle below. (Ask for a view of it when you book.) There was some noise from the adverts playing on huge screens outside, but they stopped around 11pm and didn't affect our sleep.Our rooms had most mod cons like fridge, alarm clock, flatscreen TV, and a desk with free wired internet connection. We hired a laptop from reception (Y1000 for 12 hours). My iphone was also able to jump on wifi from across the street and there was pay internet in the lobby next to the vending machines.The staff were super friendly and helpful, especially as we had to extend our stay due to the volcano in Iceland. They kept out luggage when we had some nights away from the hotel on trips.Right under the hotel are loads of restaurants if you are feeling lazy. Most have English menu's available - just ask as you go in. There are also hundreds of stores and places to eat within minutes walk. Bring a guidebook so you don't get overwhelmed by the choice!The location was great if you don't mind being in the middle of the hustle and bustle of the city as soon as you exit the hotel. There are one or two seedier streets down one side of the hotel but nothing ever felt dangerous and there are always tons of people around. You can get directly into Shibuya station from the hotel, so popular sites like Harajuku, Yoyogi Park, and the Meiji Shrine are very close, 10 mins by subway or 25 - 30 mins walk.Finally the airport Limobus pulls in right to the hotel and you can book tickets with reception. It's much better than carting suitcases around on the crowded metro.All in all a good choice.

The location of this hotel is just unbeatable. Shibuya station, with the Yamanote (or Circle) Line, Ginza, Fukutoshin & Hanzomon Lines is located almost at its doorstep. This connection came in very handy on the rainy days during my visit. There are many eateries in Mark City, where its located, and also in the many streets and alleys surrounding the hotel. My husband tried the traditional breakfast during a morning business meeting and said it was very good. I easily found breakfast at the many cafes located within Mark City. For those who come to Tokyo for shopping, you'll be spoilt for choice as there are also many department stores nearby like Tokyu & Seibu. My personal favourite was 109, located just across from the hotel. The room, while not luxurious, was very clean & completely met our needs. The toilet was a good size and had an excellent shower. The beds & pillows were probably hard by American standards (having holidayed recently in the States, I found the bedding there to be generally very soft and fluffy) but the beds were a good size and comfortable enough for us.This is my second trip to Tokyo. Having stayed at Shimbashi & Shinagawa previously, I'll definitely say this hotel in Shibuya will be my first choice for future visits.

The hotel is facing the shibuya station and the busy area of the city. The view from the top floor room is amazing. I enjoyed the fact that it was a walking distance from all the shops, malls, etc. Most of all, it has a mall at the lower floor, in the same building.

Stayed at this hotel for 5 nights for my first trip to Tokyo and wasn't disapponted. The location is perfect - right on the Shibuya crossing (which you can see wonderfully from the glss lift on the corner of the building). It gives good access to JR rail lines (handy if you have a JR rail pass) and the subway, and it's one of the stops on the limosine service from the aiport, so is very easy to get to. It's also in a brilliantly lively area packed with shops, restaurants etc. The hotel itself was a high end business hotel. We stayed in two rooms because we broke up our stay, and both were excellent. Large, big beds, and the most comfortable pillows I've ever slept on. Staff were very helpful (although spoke only a little English) and were happy to switch us from a twin room to a double etc.I will definitely return to this hotel when I go back to Tokyo.

Stayed on the 24th floor which commanded excellent panoramic view of Shibuya station. Location is one of the very best in Shibuya area. Standard size room & bath room therefore it's quite big for Japanese norms, free wired internet and daily amenities. Rooms are cleaned and neatly tucked daily. Checked in was swift, but in Japan the earliest check-in always be 14.00 Hrs. so be careful. Staff was extremely helpful tried the lobby lounge dinner which was good. There are tonnes of decent restaurants in walking distance, not to mention countless in the Shibuya station alone. (sandwich shop in the corridor connecting 2nd/3rd floor of the station is very good alternative to hotel breakfast)Price is higher but still in reasonable range. A good choice for downtown Tokyo.

This hotel was fantastic - great location, right in the heart of Shibuya, close to the train station, great view, decent rooms without being over the top (because in Shibuya, you will not spend much time in your room!) and given that we are talking about Tokyo, good value for money. I tried the Western breakfast and whilst it didn't quite hit the mark (I was dying for some toast!), it wasn't bad either. I also tried room service, which hit the spot nicely. The room was a decent size by Japanese standards.In sum, I thoroughly recommend this hotel and would not hesitate to stay here again.
poor breakfast but excellent view of Shibuya and great location to metro and all city locations.

Stayed for 5 nights. Great view, quiet and clean room. Desk staff were helpful when I needed to print something out. Breakfast on the top floor - wonderful views and friendly service. Tried the Japanese breakfast for a couple of mornings - liked it - but then switched to the Western room which was good also. Amenities in the room are fine - small fridge and hot water kettle for tea. Great location for access to the Yamanote and other subway lines....just walk downstairs. Also the Mark City mall has a few reasonable restaurants including a sushi place that always has a huge line so you know it must be good (I tried the takeout from there, it was excellent). Free wired internet in room worked fine.

Fantastic view over Tokyo from the high floors, located right next to the Shibuya station and quite large double rooms for Tokyo. Can't comment on breakfast/food as I spent most of the time outside the hotel.

I was only staying in Shibuya for two nights and I couldn't have picked a better hotel for location and convenience. The Excel is in an absolutely prime location just on the corner of the famous Shibuya crossing, and is directly opposite an entrance to the train station. Near the Hachiko entrance, which is lovely in itself. You are supposed to pat the statue's head for luck, I think!The Excel has great views, helpful staff, exceptionally clean rooms, and an exciting location- you'll never run out of things to see and do, and eat...We were allocated a room on the top floor, which was a definite upgrade from the one we had booked. It was huge, with 3 double beds and a separate toilet and bathroom- very handy when sharing with someone who takes a long time in the shower!The top floors of the hotel can only be accessed by using special security cards in the lift, which enhanced the feeling of safety and security. Glass lifts provided great views of the crossing and a soccer field on the top of a neighbouring building! Internet was available in the hall area near the lift, and the vending machines were well stocked with basics, coffee, water and beer.The only thing I found confusing was finding the hotel itself, as it's not very well marked. The entrance is located on the street level of the Shibuya Mark City building, and you enter an enclosed area and access the lift to the lobby from there. A bit of a nuisance when laden down with luggage, but my fault for not researching better before I arrived I suppose.I was very pleased with everything about the Excel, and I would love to stay there again.

We booked this hotel after reading the reviews on Trip Advisor. This Hotel didn't disappoint. From the moment we stepped into the glass lifts up to our room, we felt the buzz of Tokyo and knew we were going to love our stay. The rooms were a great size compared to other hotels we stayed in Japan. We were travelling with a 8 month old baby and there was plenty of room for his travel cot to be set up. The location can't be beaten as there were heaps of places to eat and shopping was on our doorstep. The train station was directly across from the Hotel. which meant we could active our JR pass from Shibuya Station. The Hotel staff were great. We forwarded our luggage to our next destination without any problems. They also helped us with our baby needs. I had to buy some baby formula and they helped me translate it into English. Would definitely stay here again.

We stayed for 7 nights in a non smoking Excel Twin on the 22nd floor after securing a great rate of £150/22500yen per night via expedia (rack rate is 35000yen). The hotel location is superb, adjacent to the famous Shibuya Crossing and opposite Shibuya station with access to the Ginza and JR Yamanote lines . Our room at 30m2 was large by Japanese standards and was modern in style, nothing spectacular but perfectly nice and unlike some previous reviews did have a LCD tv. Other features were free internet access, superb views of the Tokyo skyline as well as the bedlam below and a fridge for storing your own drinks (there is also a ice machine on each floor for guest use). There is a restaurant (pricey) on the top floor and a cafe at lobby level which seemed popular but we chose to eat out so cant comment on them. There are so many restaurants in the area your really spoilt for choice, for breakfast there is a patisserie and cafe one floor down from the lobby and a starbucks 2 floors down as well as many coffee shops in the immediate area. We found the staff spoke good english and were very helpful when I needed emergency dental treatment after breaking two fillings during a horrendous flight over to Japan, getting me an appointment within one hour of asking!. Shibuya is a fantastic area to stay in (far better than Shiodome where we stayed on a previous trip) and the Excel is a great option offering both value and convenience and we would certainly stay at this hotel again.

Location: Smack bang in the middle of Shibuya, you can walk to all shops and we even walked to Harajuku -> Rippongi and back.Hotel: Clean rooms, decent size and relatively luxurious for Japanese standards and for the price. Our room had a large bed, and a little lounge that overlooked the shibuya crossing below and had a great view of the Tokyo skylineStation - its on the JR line and in 15 mins you can get to the other station taht takes you to Osaka and Kyoto (ive forgoten the name starts with S) so its conveniently located. You can also use the metro to get to the fish market and emperor palace and Ginza (excellent Leica shop there called Lemon ?).Food: There is a food court at bottom of hotel so you can grab some great food for lunhc/dinner and eat out in a park or back at the room overlooking the tokyo skyline. Best Tip: there is a Okanomiyaki (japanese/korean pancake) place down the road that has a great lunch special = pancake, noodles and miso for 700yen which is a steal and probably the best meal in the area unless you like fermented bean curd soup or really bad interpretations of western fast food. The pancake place is strait accross at teh major shibuya crossing then take the path that forks to the left - past the back of HMV and past mcdonalds. I think we visited this place no fewer than 6 times during our 5 days here.Great atmosphere around the hotel and i would recommend to anyone.

We booked this hotel after reading other reviews and did not regret it. The rooms were of a good size for 2 people (after reading reviews of tokyo hotels I was expecting it to be tiny so was pleasantly suprised). The room was modern, very clean, good amenities, serviced daily, and we had a great view of the shibuya crossing as well as the shinjuku skyline which day or night was captivating. We got a non smoking room as requested. It is in an awesome location, so close to the train/subway station (1 minute) and you can easily access all areas of tokyo on the lines from here. I must admit we had breakfast at starbucks which was a couple of floors down from reception and it was good and economical. The limousine bus also goes to this hotel which helps after a long flight. Definetely recommend it.

This was our first trip to Japan and so I spent many hours researching hotels and locations. When it came down to it, we figured that if we were going to stay in Tokyo we wanted to right in the middle of things. When I realised that the Shibuya Excel was ON the center gai, I knew I had to stay here! As we had never been to Japan, we decided to catch the limousine bus directly to the hotel, which was great after a long flight. The hotel is a little hard to find, as it is a shopping mall/train station. We didn't speak to the front desk a great deal, just handed over my expedia confirmation and passport and that was it. We stayed on the 24th floor in an Excel twin which was very nice. The room was spotless and was about 30m2 which is pretty decent for a Japanese hotel room. It is a secure floor and you can only get up to it by using your room key in the elevator. The hotel was extremely quiet and we barely saw anyone else on our stay. The free adsl in the room was also a plus, just plug in the provided ethernet cable and away you go!We had a view of the other side of the city (not over the crossing) which was still pretty cool seeing as we were 24 floors up. We could still see the rooftop soccer field, which is located across the road. The lift area overlooks the crossing so every morning and night we would get a good look of the lights and activity going on below. And if you are lucky 1 of the lifts is clear and gives you a good view.We thoroughly enjoyed Shibuya and everything is a few minutes walk from the hotel which is great. Just head across the crossing and you'll find heaps of places to eat, clothing stores and multi-level malls. We deliberately walked into restaurants we couldn't understand and ended up having some amazing meals esp. okonomiyaki. If you decide to head to Harajuku, Shinjuku, Ginza etc, all of the main train lines pass through Shibuya and as the hotel is on the train station, it is easy to explore Tokyo.For the location alone, I think that the hotel was good value. Right in the heart of Shibuya and minutes on the train away from Shinjuku and Harajuku makes it great location for a holiday to Tokyo. I thoroughly enjoyed my stay and would go back.

I recently stayed at this hotel with my husband and two children aged 8 & 11 in one of the quad rooms (brilliant as very hard to fine in Tokyo). The room we stayed in has been updated, the shower and bath are separate to the toilet, the setup is four single beds with two being king singles. The room is not gigantic (bigger then the other rooms located on the same floor), had enough room for a table in the middle with four chairs and the room was very clean. I found the beds extremely comfortable and my stay excellent and even with the crossing and nightlife it was extremely quiet.The service was very polite and efficient, however they were very strict on the 2pm check- in but held our luggage until then. We were located on 10th floor at the end of the hallway near the emergency exit which was non-smoking and my suggestion is to try for the 18th (also non-smoking) as you will be able to see the large crossing. However, if you were like us and out exploring each day then it really does not matter which floor as you get an excellent view of the crossing going down the elevators nearest the windows. There is a Starbucks just around the corner once you get out at the 3rd Floor which does yummy ham and cheese rolls and also ideal for a quick breakfast before heading out to explore. The hotel is located in Mark City which also has many restaurants and is joined to Shibuya railway station which underneath is a Food hall with a great selection of bakery items as well as other food alternatives. Japan has got into a big way into pastries and bread. Location wise for transport is fantastic. There is a Limited Express that goes to and from the airport without changing at Tokyo or Shinagawa which we discovered after arriving, but took going back. It has many different lines but no Shinkansens run out of here. For dinner we found a fantastic Yakiniku and really friendly staff at Han Daidokoro (Han's Kitchen) To get there from the hotel cross over at the crossing opposite the 109 Building and then walk straight up Dogenzaka till you reach an escalator with AM/PM Shop (small mini market) and head up to the 4th floor. Definitely go, meat yummy and not too expensive when feeding a family of four.

I stayed on business for a couple of days on my own - perfect for shops and restaurants. The hotel is terrifically located in Shibuya, above a shopping complex and several restaurants. The room was standard size with few frills but the location makes the difference.Breakfast is ok (for the cost) but then again starbucks is only a floor below reception!Very easy shuttle bus to the airport like most of the hotels in Tokyo.No Gym and no bar, basic room service - but plenty of bars in the area.I will definitely return!

I usually stay at more expensive hotels in Japan but this one is good value for a lower price. The rooms are basic but still nice. Japanese service is it's usual high quality. Location can't be beat and there is an excellent Hobgoblin british pub across the street when you get tired of sushi and saki. Direct bus to airport is also a bonus but the ride is really long.

This was my first trip to Tokyo and I loved the location – busy, vibrant and convenient for the (very confusing) underground system. The shuttle bus from the airport was very useful. The hotel room/bathroom was a bit small and a bit dated but comfortable, usable and well equipped (dressing gowns, slippers, trouser press, and even some kind of sleeping gown!). However there was no room safe – I asked if I could move to a room with a safe and they said I could be upgraded to a room on one of the security floors (you needed to use your room cardkey in the lift to get to these floors) for an extra 2,500 yen per night. I went for it; the room was identical except it had a safe!Views from both rooms were brilliant (over the Shibuya crossing). The bed was comfortable and the room was quiet. Service was good and very efficient. Free internet in the room; just plug-in and go, no password/username needed. Value for money? I thought it was a bit expensive for what you got, but that’s Tokyo! In all though a very enjoyable stay, and I would definitely recommend it if you want to stay in Shibuya.

I stayed with my wife and daughter (age 10) and son (age 7) for 4 nights during our kids' Easter break. I selected the hotel because, based on my research (including hours on Tripadvisor), the Excel was one of the only hotels in Tokyo that offered a quad room. Tokyo is an expensive city, so I did not want to pay for two rooms if I could avoid it.We were very pleased with this hotel. It is not luxury. The Narita Express bus line does drop off passengers at a bus stop in the hotel complex rather than at the enterance to the hotel (so we endured the 5 minute walk). The television was a big old tube style model. The soap and shampoo are provided in big industrial pump canisters that are obviously not changed with each guest. The towels are pretty thin and the amount was insufficient for a family of four. The decor is fairly old and minimalist.But these issues are minor. The room was set up in a quite unique manor. There were two twin beds arranged with a night stand in between on each side of the room, with a table and chairs in the middle (somewhat akin to a dorm room). Each "side" had its own large window overlooking the bright lights of Shibuya, but with blackout curtains so sleeping was not an issue. There was a large closet, and the toilet was in a different room then the vanity and shower, which was convenient for 4 people.The location is amazing, as discussed in numerous prior reviews Nothing further needs to be said on that issue.What was quite unexpected considering the experiences of prior reviewers was the exceptional service that we received from the front desk. Aside from check in and check out which were flawless, the front desk provided exceptional information in regard to visiting a sumo school (which was the highlight of my trip). They ensured that it was open and available, and provided detailed directions, including providing the address in Japanese so the taxi driver outside the subway station could easily understand it. They provided detailed subway instructons so we could easily travel from place to place. They provided complete and accurate instructions on getting to and from Disney on the train. They called a restaurant owned by one of the famed "Iron Chefs" to see if the man himself was going to be there (he wasn't, unfortunately). They procurred last minute reservations at a popular Roppongi reataurant. They arranged our return transportation to the airport. The assisted us in obtaining information to go to a baseball game (a great experience).As stated in previous reviews, the hotel is located in a mall. We found that to be no problem and, in fact, the easy choices for a quick breakfast and evening snack with 2 kids in tow was welcome. As was the easy access to the Shibuya train station. Although there have been numerous comments about the size of the station, have no fear. There is a manned ticket counter at the enterance to the station from the mall, and every train is color coded. Just follow the signs. As we are trying to "train" our kids in the ways of travel, we let our kids lead the way in the train station, and even our 7 year old had no problem simply following the colored signs.My family and I cannot thank the front desk staff enough for making our Tokyo adventure a huge success. The last time that I was in Tokyo (sans kids) I stayed at the New Otani. This location is much better, and the Excel is far more family friendly.It is not world class luxury, but we received a quad room for less then most Tokyo hotels charge for a double, and we were treated to exceptional service.Arigato, Excel.

We stayed here as part of our honeymoon as we love Shibuya and the famous crossing. We requested a high-floored room with a view of the crossing and were absolutely amazed with the room we were given which was on the 24th floor directly overlooking the centre of Shibuya and the crossing.The service here was great, the rooms clean, spacious and comfortable with a seating area by the large window. Shibuya is a vibrant and buzzing place to be, we really enjoyed our stay in this hotel.What we liked most - the view and high-floored room.What we liked least - the hotel entrance is within the entrance to Shibuya Mark City which is a shopping mall with restaurants and could be a little busy but other than this, the hotel has an ideal location, being directly opposite Shibuya station.We treated ourselves to room service breakfast on a couple of occasions which was really nice, lots of variety.

Stay for business. Reservations was actually handled by local Japan office. I got a deluxe room which is a bit larger than the normal room according to the floor plan. Check in was fine and the room is fine. I didn't get a room that faces the crossing but that was alright. The room itself was nice. Large LCD TV, standard queen bed with a sofa and small desk. Bathroom was surprising large compare to other Hotel's I've stayed at in Japan. The toilet wasn't heated but had all the other electronic stuff on it.Only odd thing was the soap dispenser. They were the large industrial size pump bottle. One next to the sink and two in the shower. In the shower, one was shampoo and the other was conditioner. Since they are the large industrial size, I don't think they replace when people check in/out. Only when empty. I find that odd since I find Japanese people are very particular when it comes to personal hygiene and germs.The location of this hotel is key. It is right on top of Shibuya station. As other have noted, it faces the busiest crossing in the world. It's a sight to see. Even if you don't get a room that faces the crossing, there are windows next to the elevators that overlook the crossing. I'd spent some time just looking at the crossing at night. Since the hotel is in Shibuya, there are lot of places to eat and things to see.Close by there are several clubs and "love" hotels. Right across the street, there are plenty of shopping and restaurants. For Harley Davis fans, there is a Harley dealer/store close by. My co-working had to go there to pick up T-shirts.There is one slight warning I want to give that I think hasn't been mentioned before. Although the airport bus from Narita does stop at the hotel, there is no porter / bell hop at the main drive way. It's hard to explain but the airport bus doesn't stop in front of the hotel but at a bus stop. The bus stop is not on the street but sort of on the property of the hotel. You have to carry your baggage into the lobby of the hotel from the bus stop before you see actual porter / bell hop. The actual distance is not far at only about 100M or so. To take the bus from the hotel to Narita, you can call the front desk before check and tell them you are taking the airport bus. They will send a porter to collect your baggage and make sure it gets on the bus.Overall, it is a great location and fine place to stay while in Tokyo.

I book this hotel thru an Expedia package. 2 adult and 2 children came out to a triple room as my 14-year old is considered an adult. When I arrived, they said they don't have a triple facing the Shibuya Crossing and also, they didn't have a non-smoking room, things which I had asked for. They put us in a 9/F smoking room facing a huge flashing neon sign. The room stank of smoke and that flashing neon sign drove us bonkers. I requested something else and they put me onto the 15/F, still a smoking room but a bit better without the neon sign flashing all night. I can still smell the smoke thru the sheets and on all the upholstery.The next day, the front desk said they found me a non-smoking room on the 10/F, right in front of that flashing neon sign again. We have to pack all our stuff and move down to that room. I said I'll rather stay where I was. They then had the audacity to say I MUST move to the 10/F, there's no higher non-smoking floors. I asked to talk to the manager , it's then that they come back with an offer for a Quad, non-smoking on the 18/F, facing the crossing. So, obviously there are floors higher than the 10/F that are non-smoking; they just don't want to give it to me. I said I don't need a Quad, I just wanted to get a room that I paid for. All that arguing just to get close to what I had booked originally!So we settled in what is actually a 2-bed suite with the sofa converted to a bed and a temporary bed added. The extra beds actually stick out into the entrance. They called it a Quad but we didn't bother to argue, we just wanted to get on with our holiday. For two days, we spent in that so called Quad and we're fine. Then on the third day, we came back in the evening to find they had changed the converted bed back into a sofa and removed the fourth set of amenities! I called the front desk and ask them to return the setup we had before. They sent 2 guys from the front desk to argue that I've only booked for a Triple and that's what I'm getting. I told them I'm fine with getting a triple but it's their manager that gave us the Quad setup, now they're going back on their word?Anyway, we finally got our Quad setup back but only after much argument. I really don't need this! Throughout the ordeal, the staff were courteous but were so inflexible. I don't think they meant to screw this up so badly but lying about not having a higher non-smoking floorsand not communicating about the Quad offer to their fellow staff surely doesn't help their cause. It's like no one can deviate from the play book. They never even offer a breakfast or something to compensate for us having to spend the first night in a smoking room. The hotel itself might be fine, rooms were clean, location was great but the service has been atrocious.

I really enjoyed my stay at this hotel so much that I booked it again on my return trip. Nice rooms, great bathrooms, deep tub, high tech washy washy toilets, comfy slippers, and good food up on top of the facility. I LOVE Japanese food but not the breakfast.. so A Bennoit (upstairs restaurant) has a great western style breakfast. Great location for the hotel but I was expecting to find it easier... now I know how big Shibuya Station is. HIGHLY recommended facility.

This is quite a nice hotel. There is no doubt that the location, right in the heart of Shibuya, is fantastic. The rooms have some amazing views - well at least mine did, looking out towards Shibuya crossing. However, the rooms are on the small side, and the bathrooms are, frankly, tiny. I am not a fan of the "shower over the bath" type of arrangement. The bed was Japanese style futon like, and was very very comfortable. Good free wired internet service, which is excellent - although wireless would have been a nice. The rooms, and the overall hotel are of course very very clean. The controls for the lights etc all work and are easy to use, and well positioned by the bed. The service is good (as one would expect in Japan)- but nothing particularly special.Some problems:- The hotel has no gym or pool - and that's a huge negative for me. - My rate included breakfast at one of the restaurants on the 25th floor (western of Japanese). The restaurants are tiny, and just can't cope with the volume of visitors - there is often lines waiting for a table. On one day I missed breakfast, as the wait was 20 minutes, and I didn't have that amount of time to spare. - The western breakfast isn't very good - there is a weird combination of foods - no fresh made toast, but lots of danish etc but potato wedges and mini Kit Kats ! The quality of other foods isn't very good either - they bacon is just nasty. Would I stay there again - probably not, I would look for a place with a gym and/or pool.

We stayed for 2 weeks in a high level corner room. Absolutely magnificent view of Shibuya Crossing. Really nothing to fault at the hotel. It's a great location, the staff are helpful and friendly, the room (while small) furninshed nicely and very clean. Possibly one of the smallest bathrooms I've ever used but it was functional.Because we stayed 2 weeks - we needed to use the Hotel Laundry service. Really reasonably priced and everything came back beautifully folded and packaged (of course!). Free internet connection is also a bonus.You really can't go past this hotel if you want to stay in the middle of it all. The dollar plummeted while we were there making the cost of the room higher than we had expected but...even so....it was still worth it.

The location of this hotel is unbeatable. It's like staying at Time Square in NYC. Many big department stores are within walking distance, which makes shopping and food hunting easy, and a major subway station is right underneath the hotel.I was in love with the complimentary Japanese breakfast. They changed the side dishes (there were 9 of them, including Miso soup and dessert) everyday so I could experience different Japanese food during my two-night stay. My husband, on the other hand, was indulged in western style breakfast buffet (also complimentary) since he didn’t care too much for Japanese kind.The hotel participates in a “Green Dollar” program. The card on the toiletry tray says if no toiletry is used, the guest can bring the green coin(s) (there are two) to the front desk and the hotel will make a monetary contribution toward some environmental protection programs. I felt good when I gave the front desk my two coins because other than not wasting, I did something extra.

This hotel is kind of hard to find when you get off the train in Shibuya and are a bit disorientated but it is very close and upstairs from the mall, you just need to get your bearings.Its clean and SO quite being smack dab in the middle of Shibuya, everything is central and although the staff speak limited english they are very helpful! You can also get a buffet breakfast on the one of the top floors that gives you a wonderful view of the city, the food there was great and the view and service was wonderful! I would recommend this hotel and as i can see from the reviews so would many others. i booked this hotel based on the other reviews on Trip Advisor and am VERY glad i did.

I first heard about this property through a WIRED Magazine feature on Tokyo in 2001 -- apparently it’s the place where Japan’s dot-com deals are made. Though I’m no internet mogul I’ve stayed there four times now, in 2001, 2003, 2006 and most recently July, 2008.If you’re staying at this hotel please heed my advice and DO NOT TAKE THE EXPRESS TRAIN FROM NARITA AIRPORT. Although it will take you right to Shibuya Station (which the hotel is connected to) the station itself is so huge that you’ll easily get lost. Far better to take the Airport Limousine Bus, which will drop you off directly at the hotel’s front door, and likewise right at the check-in counter at the airport on the way back.I payed a premium for a view of the famous Shibuya Crossing (seen in the movie LOST IN TRANSLATION) -- also included in my rate was free high-speed internet in my room and complimentary daily breakfasts at either of the two restaurants on the hotel’s top floor.There’s a Japanese restaurant serving a traditional breakfast which I’ve tried out of curiosity, but like most Gaijin I needed coffee and eggs to start my days off right. The buffet western-style breakfast doesn’t disappoint, with lots of hot food choices along with fresh fruit, pastries and bread.The rooms are small but very modern, and require the presence of a key card to activate electricity and air conditioning in the room -- a bit of a hassle when the temperature outside is approaching forty degrees celsius! New to the rooms since my last stay are flat-screen plasma TVs.For 500 JPY you can get a Tokyu Hotels Membership Card, which allows you to collect points redeemable for gift certificates to help pay your bill after a few stays. Though this hotel is expensive it’s in a fantastic location and entirely worth it for that view!

Took my family ( 2 adults, 2 kids aged 8 and 10) to Tokyo last week and wanted to get a BIG reaction to staying in Tokyo on the first night. Guess what? I got it. Arrived at night so conveniently on the Limo Bus from Narita to our doorstep which was perfect for the sleepy kids. Had a quad room which is sooooo hard to find in Tokyo and this was perfect. Their little mouths dropped as they look upon the city lights with amazement from our room on the 15th floor. We could see a rooftop soccer game in play, huge numbers of people crossing at the major intersection, and a vibrant city in action. The room was just fine for us and the reality of the place is somewhat better than the photos. The shots look a little clinical and cold, but believe me, we were very happy to be here. I had considered The Mandarin and the Ritz Carlton but this place just had everything that was important to my decision. Front desk - easy check in and helpful, excellent location, clean rooms with the perfect combination for us, great shopping and restaurants. Great access to subway and rest of Tokyo. Children loved riding up and down in windowed elevators looking at the sites of the area. From Shinjuku to Yoyogi, and all over. Couldn't have been happier and paid so little for the desired effect. Surely stay there again. Great introduction to Japan, subway culture, corporate culture and shopping culture. This is where our children learnt that walking single file in rush hour is a better option than walking four abreast. Kids also took photos of rush hour commuters. Great insight into the real Tokyo. Highly recommended.

Great 4 star holiday hotel in a fabulous location. The rooms are small by western standards, but they were very clean and the furnishings were fine - really what you are paying for is the location not a room for a luxury romantic getaway. Like one of the other reviewers, we were returning from a ski trip so were not dressed up like the locals, however unlike that reviewer, we felt very comfortable walking around the hotel wearing hiking boots and outdoor wear.

My sister and I were in Tokyo for a wedding and the international out of town guests for the wedding were all housed at this hotel. Definitely top rated for location as it is situated above the train station. I found the rooms a bit smaller compared to North American standards but they were very clean. Nearby, there were lots of nightlife and easily accessible eateries. Only thing I had an issue with was a tad too much bleach used on the hotel robes.

I only stayed 1 night en route elsewhere but would gladly stay here again. Great central location! The airport limo bus drops off & picks up directly o/s hotel. I missed the bus from airport (check for sched) so decided to try the subway (1st timer & I spoke only English). Airport info desk helpful; limited english but I got by. The hotel can be accessed to/from the Shibuya underground train station; didn't even have to exit stn to reach hotel. Follow signs or ask.By U.S. stds, hotel is probably 3-1/2 stars. Clean, decent room, nice bathroom, equipped with good amenities. Room decent for 1, smallish for 2. I was upgraded to room with view & a massage chair - nice - nearly fell asleep on it especially after a long flight. Since price is reasonable, I'd consider booking a higher priced room for more space if I stayed longer.

You couldn't be more central than this hotel. Right in the middle of the action. The lobby looks nice, but the rooms are a little small especially the bathroom. It looks like there has been attempts to upgrade the room furniture but I really think all the rooms need to be completely renovated. The rooms were clean with nice bed linnen. Only 2 bath towels were provided and there was no in-room safe. Internet was free. This is not your Grand Hyatt and certainly felt like a business hotel. The hotel service was ok. The reception did not greet or speak until she was telling me what my room number was at check-in. The view from the breakfast view was amazing. The quality and variety at breadkfast was average. You have to ask to get your bread toasted. The hotel has an overnight bag courier service and can send your bags to Narita- very handy if you have large suitcases and pick them up at the airport.

I choose Shibuya Excel Hotel Tokyu because there is a shuttle transferfrom airport directly to this hotel, it is quite convenient for me andI only have 16 hours to stopover at Japan. The Tokyo airport actually quite far to the town centre. It spent around 1.5 hours from the airport to Shibuya by bus. I have booked a lady single room. When I reached hotel, it was already around 10pm. The hotel staff upgrade me to a big room which can accomodate for 4 person. Moreover, the night secene from the room is very beautiful too.

I'd say the hotel itself was your typical asian midprice to better than midprice hotel. Lobby and restaurants were first class like a hilton/hyatt, but the rooms where tiny and basic with burns on the carpet and very warm hallways. No great amenities at all. Staff spoke very basic, limited english. Location was super awesome...the action/bars/crowds/eats where right out your doorstep. Not to mention the great hub of the trains and the subway right outside just steps away.There is a higher class hotel a couple blocks down if you want more upscale, but for me the Excel was just fine and I would stay again. Hotel was 'upscale' for me, but I am used to travelling cheap...company foot the bill on this one.Paid around 17500 yen with special company rate.

Perfect location at Shibuya Station, couldn`t be better for seeing the city. The hotel is located at Mark Plaza in Shibuya, a very upscale shopping center. Everyone, and I mean everyone is dressed to the absolute nines. If you are not used to being in close quarters with lots of people in thousand dollar suits and ladies outfits, then don`t stay here. I am used to traveling fairly casually and wearing shorts, t-shirts, jeans, sneakers, etc. But, here I was very uncomfortable. This is a fairly upscale hotel, despite it`s three-star rating. Also, the ventilation in the hotel is terrible, hallways and elevators extremely hot and stuffy. I mean, such that you can`t breathe it was so bad. My skin was always clammy from the heat in the hallways and lack of ventillation. The staff was very helpful in all our requests and they all speak English quite well.

stayed for a night in april, fantastic location - close to famous shibuya cross roadsclean basic rooms on doorstep of all shibuyas shopsopposite shibuya station making it easy to get to shinjuku and harijuku too (only couple of stops on green line)english is hardly spoken but people are warm friendly and seemingly happy to helpdont get a taxi to from airport (natita) as it will cost about $200!! get fast train / limo bus insteadalso - your phne / blackberry wont work and credit cards frequently stop - phone bank and warn them well in advance as its virtually impossible to get them going again once you're there!

I stayed here in December of 2006. You really could not get a better location - next to Shibuya station which provides hugely easy access to where ever you may want to go in Tokyo and the surrounds, connected to a large shopping mall complete with restaurants, food outlets with everything from Starbucks to Dean & Deluca and pharmacies. And across the road is Shibuya itself, with department stores, international banks, teenybopper stores, 100 yen stores, music outlets and more bars and clubs than you can shake a stick at. The hotel itself is very good. I stayed on the women's only floor. Be sure to ask for a room with a view of the crossing. The view past the park in Harajuku and the skyscrapers of Shinjuku in the distance is beautiful. Being Japan, it was not a particularly large room, but there *is* actually enough room to swing a cat ;) so it is no way cramped. The room and bathroom remained spotlessly clean during my stay, and the staff were very helpful and pleasant with my many, many questions.

The hotel was highly recommended by my Japanese gf and the travel agent so I read a few travellers' reviews (which gave high ratings btw) and finally confirmed the 3nites stay at the Shibuya Excel.
